intro: Gilia gracilis var. euphorbioides, commonly known as the narrowleaf gilia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its slender, erect stems and clusters of small, showy flowers. The flowers are typically pink or red, with five petals and a distinctive, tubular throat. The plant thrives in dry, sandy soils and is often found in open habitats such as grasslands and disturbed areas. It plays a role in supporting pollinators and is sometimes used in restoration projects due to its hardy nature.
